title: New Hostilities Over Huawei Threaten Collateral Damage for U.S. Techs
summary:
It's been a year as of this weekend since the United States blacklisted Huawei Technologies.
Shenzhen-based Huawei started its annual analyst meeting on Monday, and will be streaming it from headquarters over the next three days.
The U.S. Commerce Department said such a move demonstrated "good will," suggesting it may get a break on dealing with Huawei.
Officially, China's Ministry of Commerce on Sunday urged the United States to stop its "wrong actions" and abuse of export controls.
It noted that Huawei has been indicted in New York court for exporting products from the United States to Iran, in violation of sanctions.
authors: New Hostilities Over Huawei Threaten Collateral Damage For U.S. Techs
Boeing Are All Named In The Firing Line As China Prepares Defenses Against U.S. Commerce Department Attack.
text:
It's been a year as of this weekend since the United States blacklisted Huawei Technologies. So for good measure, the U.S. Commerce Department is upping the ante by banning sales of chips to Huawei that are made with U.S. technology, even if they're made outside the United States.

China is set to retaliate. That means the trade war over China's best-known telecom brand has started a new skirmish, one that could cause collateral damage to major U.S. tech names such as Apple (AAPL) .

Shenzhen-based Huawei started its annual analyst meeting on Monday, and will be streaming it from headquarters over the next three days. It's normally when Huawei unveils its latest innovations, to great fanfare.

Instead, it is fending off the latest salvo from U.S. Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross. To get around the blacklisting on national security grounds last year, Ross says Huawei has responded with an "indigenization effort," in which it gets chipsets made to its specifications outside the United States, using U.S. software and technology.

"This is not how a responsible global corporate citizen behaves," Ross said. So he announced a change in the rules to restrict semiconductor purchases abroad if linked to U.S. tech, to stop them from "enabling malign activities." There will be a 120-day grace period before that kicks in.

The share price of chipmakers such as SK Hynix from South Korea were hurt on Monday, falling 1.0% in Seoul on a day Korean shares rose 0.7%. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) , the world's biggest contract chipmaker, fell 2.7% in Taipei, with the Nikkei reporting that TSMC has stopped new orders from Huawei in response to Washington's moves.

TSMC said on Friday it will build a US$12 billion plant in Arizona. The U.S. Commerce Department said such a move demonstrated "good will," suggesting it may get a break on dealing with Huawei.

China vows revenge. It will take a "series of countermeasures," according to the official Global Times newspaper, used to spread China's foreign-policy intent abroad. They include imposing restrictions on U.S. companies such as Apple, and stopping airplane purchases from Boeing BA, the paper says, quoting a "source close to the Chinese government," which means the Chinese government.

It's the first time that specific U.S. target companies have been identified. The headline states that "China readies biggest counterattack against US."

China may add U.S. companies to its own "unreliable entity list," and launch "endless investigations" into or impose restrictions on Qualcomm (QCOM) , Cisco (CSCO) and Apple, to name a few. It may scrutinize them under China's Cybersecurity Review Measures and its Anti-monopoly Law. These punitive measures against large U.S. techs would be the "nuke bomb," and would let the U.S. companies "feel the pain," according to sources quoted by the Global Times.

Officially, China's Ministry of Commerce on Sunday urged the United States to stop its "wrong actions" and abuse of export controls. China said it would take "all necessary measures" to defend the legal rights of Chinese companies.

The U.S. Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security added Huawei and 68 of its subsidiaries in different countries to its "Entity List" on May 16, 2019. It explained that "there is reasonable cause to believe that Huawei has been involved in activities contrary to the national security or foreign policy interests of the United States." It noted that Huawei has been indicted in New York court for exporting products from the United States to Iran, in violation of sanctions.

(Apple is a holding in Jim Cramer's Action Alerts PLUS member club. Want to be alerted before Jim Cramer buys or sells AAPL? Learn more now.)

        <div class="article-author-rail__page">
            <div class="article__body article-author-rail__body"
                 itemprop="articleBody">
                <div data-paragraph-count="13" class="placement-fixed" id="div-placement-fixed-0.1736868366923514" data-total-word-count="605" data-article-has-video="false" data-article-fixed-placement="articleTop"></div><div id="div-placement-fixed-0.13060515738539802" class="placement-fixed" data-page-count="1" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-total-page-count="1" data-article-fixed-placement="pageTop"></div> <div id="div-placement-para-0.5442397439571012" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="48" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="0" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="1" data-article-word-count-so-far="0" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="1" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>It's been a year as of this weekend since the United States blacklisted Huawei Technologies. So for good measure, the U.S. Commerce Department is upping the ante by banning sales of chips to Huawei that are made with U.S. technology, even if they're made outside the United States.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.5076618066252181" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="36" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="48" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="2" data-article-word-count-so-far="48" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="2" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>China is set to retaliate. That means the trade war over China's best-known telecom brand has started a new skirmish, one that could cause collateral damage to major U.S. tech names such as Apple (<a href="/quote/AAPL.html">AAPL</a>) .</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.09132092080769472" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="32" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="84" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="3" data-article-word-count-so-far="84" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="3" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>Shenzhen-based Huawei started its annual analyst meeting on Monday, and will be streaming it from headquarters over the next three days. It's normally when Huawei unveils its latest innovations, to great fanfare.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.7002897149172538" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="53" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="116" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="4" data-article-word-count-so-far="116" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="4" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>Instead, it is fending off the latest salvo from U.S. Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross. To get around the blacklisting on national security grounds last year, Ross says Huawei has responded with an "indigenization effort," in which it gets chipsets made to its specifications outside the United States, using U.S. software and technology.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.43108840136465143" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="48" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="169" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="5" data-article-word-count-so-far="169" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="5" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>"This is not how a responsible global corporate citizen behaves," Ross said. So he announced a <a href="https://www.commerce.gov/news/press-releases/2020/05/commerce-addresses-huaweis-efforts-undermine-entity-list-restricts">change in the rules</a> to restrict semiconductor purchases abroad if linked to U.S. tech, to stop them from "enabling malign activities." There will be a 120-day grace period before that kicks in.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.732826751371263" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="59" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="217" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="6" data-article-word-count-so-far="217" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="6" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>The share price of chipmakers such as SK Hynix from South Korea were hurt on Monday, falling 1.0% in Seoul on a day Korean shares rose 0.7%. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (<a href="/quote/TSM.html">TSM</a>) , the world's biggest contract chipmaker, fell 2.7% in Taipei, with the <em>Nikkei</em> reporting that TSMC has stopped new orders from Huawei in response to Washington's moves.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.17464525974868728" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="34" data-page-paragraph-middle="true" data-page-word-count-so-far="276" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="7" data-article-word-count-so-far="276" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="7" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>TSMC said on Friday it will build a US$12 billion plant in Arizona. The U.S. Commerce Department said such a move demonstrated "good will," suggesting it may get a break on dealing with Huawei.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.4058200784779704" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="57" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="310" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="8" data-article-word-count-so-far="310" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="8" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>China vows revenge. It will take a "series of countermeasures," according to the official <em>Global Times</em> newspaper, used to spread China's foreign-policy intent abroad. They include imposing restrictions on U.S. companies such as Apple, and stopping airplane purchases from Boeing BA, the paper says, quoting a "source close to the Chinese government," which means the Chinese government.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.42036015987844133" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="22" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="367" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="9" data-article-word-count-so-far="367" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="9" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>It's the first time that specific U.S. target companies have been identified. The <a href="https://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1188493.shtml">headline states</a> that "China readies biggest counterattack against US."</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.8157278865145865" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="73" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="389" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="10" data-article-word-count-so-far="389" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="10" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>China may add U.S. companies to its own "unreliable entity list," and launch "endless investigations" into or impose restrictions on Qualcomm (<a href="/quote/QCOM.html">QCOM</a>) , Cisco (<a href="/quote/CSCO.html">CSCO</a>) and Apple, to name a few. It may scrutinize them under China's Cybersecurity Review Measures and its Anti-monopoly Law. These punitive measures against large U.S. techs would be the "nuke bomb," and would let the U.S. companies "feel the pain," according to sources quoted by the <em>Global Times</em>.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.05088920239006245" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="37" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="462" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="11" data-article-word-count-so-far="462" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="11" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>Officially, China's Ministry of Commerce on Sunday urged the United States to stop its "wrong actions" and abuse of export controls. China said it would take "all necessary measures" to defend the legal rights of Chinese companies.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.9320547451629124" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="80" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="499" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="12" data-article-word-count-so-far="499" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="12" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p>The U.S. Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security added Huawei and 68 of its subsidiaries in different countries to its "Entity List" on May 16, 2019. It explained that "there is reasonable cause to believe that Huawei has been involved in activities contrary to the national security or foreign policy interests of the United States." It noted that Huawei has been indicted in New York court for exporting products from the United States to Iran, in violation of sanctions.</p> <div id="div-placement-para-0.23473240044553223" data-image-at-index="-1" class="placement-para" data-paragraph-word-count-total="26" data-page-paragraph-middle="false" data-page-word-count-so-far="579" data-page-word-count-total="606" data-page-paragraph-count-total="13" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far="13" data-article-word-count-so-far="579" data-article-word-count-total="605" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far="13" data-article-paragraph-count-total="13"></div><p><em>(Apple is a holding in Jim Cramer's <a href="https://secure2.thestreet.com/cap/prm.do?OID=038652">Action Alerts PLUS member club</a>. Want to be alerted before Jim Cramer buys or sells AAPL? <a href="https://secure2.thestreet.com/cap/prm.do?OID=038652">Learn more now</a><a href="https://secure2.thestreet.com/cap/prm.do?OID=038652">.</a>)</em></p> <div data-paragraph-count="13" class="placement-fixed" id="div-placement-fixed-0.4944919014327781" data-total-word-count="605" data-article-has-video="false" data-article-fixed-placement="pageEnd"></div><div data-paragraph-count="13" class="placement-fixed" id="div-placement-fixed-0.8214774836916303" data-total-word-count="605" data-article-has-video="false" data-article-fixed-placement="articleEnd"></div>
            </div>

    <script>
        (function(){
            var articleModel = {"hideArticleImage":false,"slides":{},"callout":"Apple, Qualcomm, Cisco and Boeing are all named in the firing line as China prepares defenses against U.S. Commerce Department attack.","pagination":{"currentArticleUrl":"/investing/new-hostilities-over-huawei-threaten-collateral-damage-for-u-s-techs-15325145","nextArticleUrl":"/json/article/related/144/15325145/1?type=json&excludeId=15325145","currentArticleDataUrl":"/investing/new-hostilities-over-huawei-threaten-collateral-damage-for-u-s-techs-15325145?type=json","nextArticleDataUrl":"/json/article/related/144/15325145/1?type=json&excludeId=15325145"},"footer":"<p>At the time of publication, Alex Frew McMillan had no position in the securities mentioned.<\/p>","articleImageUrl":"//s.thestreet.com/files/tsc/v2008/photos/contrib/uploads/e00ead4f-78b6-11e9-9035-1b69ab6450b9.jpg","isExternalContributor":false,"publishDate":new Date(1589803332000),"primaryAuthorUrl":"/author/1684257/alex-frew-mcmillan/all.html","siteName":"Real Money","mediumThumbUrl":"//s.thestreet.com/files/tsc/v2008/photos/contrib/uploads/e00ead4f-78b6-11e9-9035-1b69ab6450b9_300x240.jpg","leadTicker":"[\"AAPL\",\"TSM\",\"QCOM\",\"CSCO\"]","categoryName":"RealMoney.com","publishDateFormatted":"2020-05-18T08:02:12.000Z","compactPubDate":"8:02 AM","numPages":1,"subcategoryName":"Global Equity & Income - RM ","lastPublishDate":"2020-05-18T08:02:12.000-0400","pages":{"0":{"number":1,"pageTitle":"New Hostilities Over Huawei Threaten Collateral Damage for U.S. Techs - RealMoney","isLastPage":true,"body":"<div data-paragraph-count=\"13\" class=\"placement-fixed\" id=\"div-placement-fixed-0.1736868366923514\" data-total-word-count=\"605\" data-article-has-video=\"false\" data-article-fixed-placement=\"articleTop\"><\/div><div id=\"div-placement-fixed-0.13060515738539802\" class=\"placement-fixed\" data-page-count=\"1\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-total-page-count=\"1\" data-article-fixed-placement=\"pageTop\"><\/div> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.5442397439571012\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"48\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"0\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"1\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"0\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"1\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>It's been a year as of this weekend since the United States blacklisted Huawei Technologies. So for good measure, the U.S. Commerce Department is upping the ante by banning sales of chips to Huawei that are made with U.S. technology, even if they're made outside the United States.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.5076618066252181\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"36\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"48\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"2\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"48\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"2\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>China is set to retaliate. That means the trade war over China's best-known telecom brand has started a new skirmish, one that could cause collateral damage to major U.S. tech names such as Apple (<a href=\"/quote/AAPL.html\">AAPL<\/a>) .<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.09132092080769472\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"32\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"84\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"3\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"84\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"3\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>Shenzhen-based Huawei started its annual analyst meeting on Monday, and will be streaming it from headquarters over the next three days. It's normally when Huawei unveils its latest innovations, to great fanfare.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.7002897149172538\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"53\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"116\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"4\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"116\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"4\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>Instead, it is fending off the latest salvo from U.S. Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross. To get around the blacklisting on national security grounds last year, Ross says Huawei has responded with an \"indigenization effort,\" in which it gets chipsets made to its specifications outside the United States, using U.S. software and technology.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.43108840136465143\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"48\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"169\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"5\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"169\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"5\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>\"This is not how a responsible global corporate citizen behaves,\" Ross said. So he announced a <a href=\"https://www.commerce.gov/news/press-releases/2020/05/commerce-addresses-huaweis-efforts-undermine-entity-list-restricts\">change in the rules<\/a> to restrict semiconductor purchases abroad if linked to U.S. tech, to stop them from \"enabling malign activities.\" There will be a 120-day grace period before that kicks in.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.732826751371263\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"59\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"217\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"6\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"217\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"6\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>The share price of chipmakers such as SK Hynix from South Korea were hurt on Monday, falling 1.0% in Seoul on a day Korean shares rose 0.7%. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (<a href=\"/quote/TSM.html\">TSM<\/a>) , the world's biggest contract chipmaker, fell 2.7% in Taipei, with the <em>Nikkei<\/em> reporting that TSMC has stopped new orders from Huawei in response to Washington's moves.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.17464525974868728\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"34\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"true\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"276\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"7\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"276\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"7\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>TSMC said on Friday it will build a US$12 billion plant in Arizona. The U.S. Commerce Department said such a move demonstrated \"good will,\" suggesting it may get a break on dealing with Huawei.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.4058200784779704\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"57\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"310\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"8\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"310\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"8\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>China vows revenge. It will take a \"series of countermeasures,\" according to the official <em>Global Times<\/em> newspaper, used to spread China's foreign-policy intent abroad. They include imposing restrictions on U.S. companies such as Apple, and stopping airplane purchases from Boeing BA, the paper says, quoting a \"source close to the Chinese government,\" which means the Chinese government.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.42036015987844133\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"22\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"367\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"9\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"367\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"9\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>It's the first time that specific U.S. target companies have been identified. The <a href=\"https://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1188493.shtml\">headline states<\/a> that \"China readies biggest counterattack against US.\"<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.8157278865145865\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"73\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"389\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"10\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"389\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"10\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>China may add U.S. companies to its own \"unreliable entity list,\" and launch \"endless investigations\" into or impose restrictions on Qualcomm (<a href=\"/quote/QCOM.html\">QCOM<\/a>) , Cisco (<a href=\"/quote/CSCO.html\">CSCO<\/a>) and Apple, to name a few. It may scrutinize them under China's Cybersecurity Review Measures and its Anti-monopoly Law. These punitive measures against large U.S. techs would be the \"nuke bomb,\" and would let the U.S. companies \"feel the pain,\" according to sources quoted by the <em>Global Times<\/em>.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.05088920239006245\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"37\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"462\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"11\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"462\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"11\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>Officially, China's Ministry of Commerce on Sunday urged the United States to stop its \"wrong actions\" and abuse of export controls. China said it would take \"all necessary measures\" to defend the legal rights of Chinese companies.<\/p> <div id=\"div-placement-para-0.9320547451629124\" data-image-at-index=\"-1\" class=\"placement-para\" data-paragraph-word-count-total=\"80\" data-page-paragraph-middle=\"false\" data-page-word-count-so-far=\"499\" data-page-word-count-total=\"606\" data-page-paragraph-count-total=\"13\" data-page-paragraph-count-so-far=\"12\" data-article-word-count-so-far=\"499\" data-article-word-count-total=\"605\" data-article-paragraph-count-so-far=\"12\" data-article-paragraph-count-total=\"13\"><\/div><p>The U.S. Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security added Huawei and 68 of its subsidiaries in different countries to its \"Entity List\" on May 16, 2019.
